title: Nystagmus Evaluation
scope: ** Systematic evaluation and management of acquired nystagmus in adults. Covers classification (central vs. peripheral), bedside examination techniques (HINTS exam, gaze testing, positional maneuvers), differentiation of nystagmus subtypes (gaze-evoked, downbeat, upbeat, periodic alternating, see-saw, convergence-retraction, vestibular), VNG/ENG and advanced vestibular testing, neuroimaging indications, and targeted treatment of specific nystagmus types (4-aminopyridine for downbeat nystagmus, baclofen for periodic alternating nystagmus, gabapentin/memantine for acquired pendular nystagmus). Excludes congenital/infantile nystagmus (brief mention), physiologic endpoint nystagmus, and comprehensive vertigo/dizziness evaluation (see Vertigo/Dizziness Evaluation template).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screening; anemia (exacerbates dizziness/oscillopsia); baseline before treatment
Electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia causes central nystagmus); hepatic/renal dysfunction affects drug metabolism; hypomagnesemia lowers threshold
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyponatremia <130 — correct and reassess nystagmus; hepatic dysfunction — medication adjustment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypoglycemia causes neurologic symptoms including nystagmus; Wernicke encephalopathy association
Essential/Core Labs.target: 70-180 mg/dL; hypoglycemia — correct; persistent low — evaluate further

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia causes nystagmus and cerebellar dysfunction; depleted by alcohol, diuretics, PPI use
Thyroid dysfunction affects vestibular and oculomotor function; hyperthyroidism causes tremor/jerky saccades
Wernicke encephalopathy (nystagmus + ataxia + confusion); ALWAYS suspect in alcoholism, malnutrition, bariatric surgery, hyperemesis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; **DO NOT WAIT for level before treating** — empiric thiamine if suspected

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and lacosamide toxicity cause gaze-evoked nystagmus; lithium toxicity causes downbeat nystagmus
Essential/Core Labs.target: Therapeutic range; supratherapeutic — dose reduction; toxic — hold medication

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Acute alcohol intoxication causes gaze-evoked and positional nystagmus; chronic alcoholism — Wernicke/cerebellar degeneration
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; positive — quantify; treat Wernicke empirically

Extended Workup.rationale: B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with ataxia and nystagmus
Folate deficiency contributes to cerebellar dysfunction, especially in alcoholism
Vitamin E deficiency causes spinocerebellar syndrome with nystagmus; malabsorption syndromes
Extended Workup.target: Normal; low — supplement and evaluate malabsorption

Extended Workup.rationale: Inflammatory/autoimmune processes (MS, neurosarcoidosis, vasculitis) causing central nystagmus
Autoimmune conditions causing CNS inflammation (SLE cerebritis, neurosarcoidosis)
Neurosarcoidosis causes brainstem/cerebellar lesions with nystagmus
Extended Workup.target: Normal; elevated — chest imaging, evaluate for neurosarcoidosis

Extended Workup.rationale: Neurosyphilis causes Argyll Robertson pupils and nystagmus; tabes dorsalis
Extended Workup.target: Negative; positive — FTA-ABS confirmation, CSF analysis

Extended Workup.rationale: GAD65 autoimmunity causes cerebellar ataxia with downbeat nystagmus; progressive cerebellar syndrome
Extended Workup.target: Negative; positive — autoimmune cerebellar disease; initiate immunotherapy

Extended Workup.item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (anti-Yo, anti-Hu, anti-Tr/DNER, anti-CV2, anti-mGluR1) (CPT 86255)
Extended Workup.rationale: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration presents with nystagmus (often downbeat) + progressive ataxia
Extended Workup.target: Negative; positive — urgent malignancy search (CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, PET)

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Autoimmune encephalitis with oculomotor abnormalities; limbic encephalitis with nystagmus
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive — autoimmune encephalitis workup, immunotherapy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Anti-IgLON5 disease causes oculomotor dysfunction including nystagmus, sleep disorder, gait ataxia
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive — sleep study, tau pathology evaluation

Rare/Specialized.item: Genetic testing (SCA panel, episodic ataxia genes) (CPT 81479)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Spinocerebellar ataxias (SCA1, 2, 3, 6, 7); episodic ataxia type 2 (CACNA1A); Friedreich ataxia
Rare/Specialized.target: Specific mutations; SCA6 and EA2 both involve CACNA1A; SCA — progressive; EA2 — episodic with interictal nystagmus

Rare/Specialized.rationale: MS (oligoclonal bands), neurosarcoidosis, leptomeningeal disease, CNS infection, autoimmune encephalitis
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal in degenerative; OCBs — MS; pleocytosis — infection/inflammation; cytology — malignancy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Wilson disease causes wing-beating tremor and oculomotor dysfunction including nystagmus in young adults
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal ceruloplasmin >20 mg/dL; low — 24h urine copper, slit lamp for KF rings

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Celiac disease causes cerebellar ataxia with nystagmus ("gluten ataxia") even without GI symptoms
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; positive — gluten-free diet, anti-gliadin antibodies

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome; genetic CJD presents with cerebellar ataxia and nystagmus
Rare/Specialized.target: No pathogenic mutation; mutation — genetic counseling

Lumbar Puncture.timing: Indicated if MS, neurosarcoidosis, autoimmune encephalitis, CNS infection, or leptomeningeal disease suspected; NOT routine for isolated nystagmus; perform after MRI
Lumbar Puncture.target: Opening pressure normal (10-20 cm H2O); **MS:** oligoclonal bands, elevated IgG index; **Neurosarcoid:** pleocytosis, elevated protein, low glucose; **Infection:** per organism; **Autoimmune:** specific antibodies
Lumbar Puncture.contraindications: Posterior fossa mass on imaging; elevated ICP without imaging; coagulopathy

Essential/First-line.timing: **CRITICAL first step**; systematic assessment: gaze in 9 cardinal positions, fixation removal (Frenzel goggles), head-shaking nystagmus, positional testing, HINTS exam if acute vestibular syndrome
Essential/First-line.target: Nystagmus pattern classification (see Section 5 — Differential Diagnosis); direction, waveform, effect of fixation, positional component

Essential/First-line.item: **HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew)**
Essential/First-line.timing: **ONLY for acute vestibular syndrome** (continuous vertigo + nystagmus >24h); more sensitive than early MRI for posterior fossa stroke; trained examiner required
Essential/First-line.target: **Peripheral:** Positive HIT + unidirectional nystagmus + no skew; **Central:** Normal HIT + direction-changing/vertical nystagmus + skew deviation — STAT MRI
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Not valid for episodic or positional nystagmus; requires acute continuous nystagmus; examiner training required

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: **Gold standard for central nystagmus evaluation**; includes DWI for stroke, FLAIR for demyelination, thin cuts through posterior fossa; MRI protocol includes craniocervical junction (downbeat nystagmus — Chiari malformation)
Essential/First-line.target: Stroke (DWI restriction); MS plaques (brainstem/cerebellum); Chiari malformation (cerebellar tonsillar herniation >5 mm); tumor (vestibular schwannoma, brainstem glioma, cerebellar metastasis); cerebellar degeneration (atrophy)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia; renal impairment (for gadolinium)

Essential/First-line.timing: **NOT sensitive for posterior fossa pathology** (beam-hardening artifact); use only if MRI unavailable or for acute hemorrhage screening; does NOT rule out posterior circulation stroke or demyelination
Essential/First-line.target: Hemorrhage; large mass; hydrocephalus; **NEGATIVE CT does NOT exclude posterior fossa pathology**

Essential/First-line.item: MRA head and neck (CPT 70544, 70547) or CTA head/neck (CPT 70496, 70498)
Essential/First-line.timing: If central nystagmus with stroke concern; vertebral artery dissection; basilar artery stenosis/occlusion; vertebrobasilar insufficiency
Essential/First-line.target: Vertebral/basilar artery dissection; stenosis; occlusion; dolichoectasia compressing brainstem
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRA: MRI contraindications; CTA: contrast allergy, renal impairment

Extended.timing: Comprehensive oculomotor and vestibular testing; spontaneous nystagmus, gaze testing, positional testing, Dix-Hallpike, caloric testing; quantifies nystagmus; documents central vs. peripheral patterns
Extended.target: Gaze-evoked nystagmus (central); unilateral caloric weakness (peripheral); direction-changing positional nystagmus (central); fixation suppression failure (central)
Extended.contraindications: Perforated TM (water calorics — use air); bilateral vestibular loss limits caloric utility

Extended.timing: Quantitative VOR assessment for all 6 semicircular canals; more sensitive than bedside HIT; differentiates peripheral from central vestibular lesions
Extended.target: Reduced VOR gain (<0.8) with corrective saccades — peripheral lesion; normal gain with central nystagmus — central lesion; canal-specific identification

Extended.timing: Hearing assessment when vestibular nystagmus present; identifies Meniere's disease, vestibular schwannoma, labyrinthitis; sudden sensorineural hearing loss is emergency
Extended.target: Normal (isolated nystagmus); low-frequency SNHL — Meniere's; asymmetric SNHL — vestibular schwannoma; mixed hearing loss — SSCD

Extended.timing: High-resolution T2 (CISS/FIESTA) for vestibular schwannoma; vascular loop compression of CN VIII; when asymmetric hearing loss or unilateral vestibular nystagmus
Extended.target: Vestibular schwannoma; vascular loop; arachnoid cyst

Extended.timing: When positional nystagmus suspected (BPPV); upbeat-torsional nystagmus with latency and limited duration = posterior canal BPPV
Extended.target: **Positive:** Upbeating-torsional nystagmus, 2-20 sec latency, <60 sec duration, fatigable — posterior canal BPPV; **Atypical:** No latency, persistent, non-fatigable — central positional nystagmus
Extended.contraindications: Cervical spine instability; severe carotid stenosis (modify technique)

Extended.timing: If MS suspected; optic nerve demyelination; confirms optic nerve involvement in clinically isolated syndrome
Extended.target: Prolonged P100 latency — optic nerve demyelination (even subclinical); supports MS diagnosis

Extended.timing: If seizure-related nystagmus (oculogyric episodes) or epileptic nystagmus suspected; also if episodic nystagmus with altered awareness
Extended.target: Normal; epileptiform discharges; seizure-related eye deviation

Rare/Specialized.timing: Saccular (cVEMP) and utricular (oVEMP) function; superior semicircular canal dehiscence; Meniere's disease; vestibular schwannoma
Rare/Specialized.target: Abnormal in SSCD (enhanced cVEMP/oVEMP); reduced/absent in vestibular schwannoma; asymmetric in Meniere's

Rare/Specialized.timing: Quantitative VOR across frequencies; bilateral vestibular hypofunction; pharmaceutical ototoxicity monitoring
Rare/Specialized.target: Bilateral vestibular loss (reduced gain across frequencies); phase/gain abnormalities; asymmetric VOR

Rare/Specialized.timing: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome; cholesteatoma; temporal bone fracture; when sound/pressure-induced nystagmus
Rare/Specialized.target: Dehiscence of superior canal; bony erosion; fracture line

Rare/Specialized.timing: Retinal nerve fiber layer thinning in chronic MS, neurodegenerative conditions; baseline for monitoring
Rare/Specialized.target: RNFL thinning — chronic optic neuropathy; normal in acute

Rare/Specialized.timing: Quantitative analysis of saccades, smooth pursuit, optokinetic nystagmus; distinguish types of cerebellar oculomotor dysfunction
Rare/Specialized.target: Saccadic dysmetria; impaired pursuit; gaze-holding failure; specific patterns for cerebellar vs. brainstem lesions

Rare/Specialized.timing: If downbeat nystagmus — evaluate craniocervical junction; Chiari malformation, craniocervical instability, foramen magnum lesion
Rare/Specialized.target: Chiari I malformation (tonsillar herniation >5 mm); foramen magnum tumor; basilar invagination; syrinx

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Wernicke encephalopathy (nystagmus + ataxia + confusion triad; may be incomplete)

dosing.instructions: **Thiamine 500 mg IV TID x 3-5 days, then 250 mg IV daily x 3-5 days, then 100 mg PO daily indefinitely**; give BEFORE glucose; [Galvin et al. (2010)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20642790/)

Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Monitor clinical improvement in nystagmus, ataxia, confusion; improvement within hours to days supports diagnosis; anaphylaxis rare with IV thiamine

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Correct electrolyte abnormalities** Per specific electrolyte IV

dosing.instructions: **Hyponatremia:** Correct slowly (max 8-10 mEq/L per 24h to avoid osmotic demyelination); **Hypomagnesemia:** MgSO4 2-4 g IV over 30-60 min then maintenance; **Hypocalcemia:** Calcium gluconate 1-2 g IV
dosing.orderSentence: **Correct electrolyte abnormalities** Per specific electrolyte IV

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Overcorrection of sodium — osmotic demyelination syndrome
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Electrolytes q4-6h during correction; neurologic reassessment after correction

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Discontinue/reduce offending medication** Hold or reduce dose -

dosing.instructions: **Phenytoin toxicity:** Hold doses until level <20 mcg/mL; **Carbamazepine toxicity:** Hold until level <12 mcg/mL; **Lithium toxicity:** Hold; hydration; hemodialysis if severe; **Aminoglycosides:** Discontinue if vestibulotoxicity confirmed
dosing.orderSentence: **Discontinue/reduce offending medication** Hold or reduce dose -

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Clinical necessity of medication; consult prescribing specialist
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Drug levels; nystagmus reassessment after dose adjustment; permanent vestibulotoxicity possible with aminoglycosides

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute-onset nystagmus with ANY central features (direction-changing, vertical, gaze-evoked without drug cause, skew deviation, normal HIT)

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Rule out posterior circulation stroke** HINTS exam -

dosing.instructions: **If ANY central pattern on HINTS:** STAT MRI with DWI + MRA head/neck; neurology/stroke consultation; activate stroke protocol if within window; [Kattah et al. (2009)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19762709/)
dosing.orderSentence: **Rule out posterior circulation stroke** HINTS exam -

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Do not delay for MRI if basilar artery occlusion suspected
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: HINTS more sensitive than early CT or MRI for posterior fossa stroke; negative CT does NOT exclude stroke

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute peripheral vestibular nystagmus with oscillopsia, nausea, or vertigo; **SHORT-TERM ONLY (24-72h)**; avoid in central nystagmus until etiology established

dosing.instructions: **Meclizine 25 mg PO q6-8h PRN**; limit to 48-72h maximum; taper as tolerated

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Avoid in central nystagmus until etiology established; prolonged use delays vestibular compensation; anticholinergic effects in elderly; urinary retention; glaucoma
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Limit to 72h; sedation; early vestibular rehabilitation once acute phase resolved

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute peripheral vestibular nystagmus with nausea and vertigo; **SHORT-TERM ONLY (24-72h)**; avoid in central nystagmus until etiology established

dosing.instructions: **Dimenhydrinate 50 mg PO or IV q6h PRN**; limit to 48-72h maximum

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Avoid in central nystagmus until etiology established; prolonged use delays vestibular compensation; anticholinergic effects in elderly; sedation
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Limit to 72h; sedation; anticholinergic side effects

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Acute vestibular nystagmus with severe vertigo; potent vestibular suppressant; **SHORT-TERM ONLY (24-72h)**

dosing.instructions: **Diazepam 2-5 mg PO or IV q8h PRN**; limit to 48-72h maximum; taper rapidly

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: Respiratory depression; CNS depression; avoid in elderly; avoid in hepatic impairment; dependency risk
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: Respiratory status; sedation level; fall risk; limit to 72h; avoid in suspected central cause until stroke excluded

Acute/Emergent Treatment.indication: Nausea and vomiting associated with acute vestibular nystagmus; antiemetic without vestibular suppressant effect

dosing.instructions: **Ondansetron 4-8 mg IV or PO q8h PRN for nausea**

Acute/Emergent Treatment.contraindications: QT prolongation; serotonin syndrome risk with serotonergic agents; hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)
Acute/Emergent Treatment.monitoring: QTc monitoring if prolonged use; constipation

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.indication: First-line for symptomatic downbeat nystagmus; potassium channel blocker that improves Purkinje cell function

dosing.instructions: **4-Aminopyridine 5 mg PO BID (compounded)** or **Dalfampridine (Ampyra) 10 mg PO BID** (extended-release); [Strupp et al. (2003)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12874393/); [Claassen et al. (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23813743/)

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.contraindications: **Seizure disorder** (lowers seizure threshold); renal impairment (CrCl <50 — dose adjustment); hepatic impairment; cardiac arrhythmia (prolongs QT at supratherapeutic doses)
Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.monitoring: Seizure risk; ECG at baseline; renal function; therapeutic response assessment at 2-4 weeks; visual acuity improvement

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.indication: Alternative to 4-AP for downbeat nystagmus; lower seizure risk than 4-AP

dosing.instructions: **3,4-Diaminopyridine 10 mg PO TID, titrate to max 20 mg TID (80 mg/day)**; [Kalla et al. (2007)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17664175/)

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.contraindications: Seizure disorder (lower risk than 4-AP but still present); QT prolongation

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.indication: Second-line for downbeat nystagmus; GABAergic effect on vestibular nuclei

dosing.instructions: **Clonazepam 0.5 mg PO BID, titrate to max 1 mg TID**; improves oscillopsia; [Dieterich et al. (1991)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1654396/)

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.contraindications: Sedation; respiratory depression; falls in elderly; dependency with long-term use; cognitive impairment
Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; fall risk; respiratory status; avoid abrupt discontinuation; limit duration

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.indication: Third-line for downbeat nystagmus; GABAergic mechanism

dosing.instructions: **Baclofen 5 mg PO TID, titrate to 10-20 mg TID**; less evidence than 4-AP

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.contraindications: Renal impairment; sedation; withdrawal seizures if abruptly stopped
Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.monitoring: Sedation; muscle weakness; renal function; slow taper if discontinuing

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.indication: Chiari malformation; craniocervical junction pathology; MS; cerebellar degeneration

dosing.instructions: **Chiari malformation:** Neurosurgical referral for posterior fossa decompression if symptomatic; **MS:** Disease-modifying therapy; **Paraneoplastic:** Immunotherapy + malignancy treatment; **Nutritional:** Vitamin supplementation

Type-Specific Nystagmus Treatment.monitoring: Nystagmus may improve or persist depending on degree of irreversible cerebellar damage

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Delays central compensation; masks underlying pathology; sedation; fall risk

dosing.instructions: Limit to 48-72h for acute peripheral vestibular nystagmus; NOT indicated for central nystagmus types

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Monitor duration of use; initiate vestibular rehabilitation early

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Vestibulotoxic — causes permanent bilateral vestibular hypofunction with oscillopsia; irreversible

doseOptions.orderSentence: **Aminoglycosides** (gentamicin, tobramycin, streptomycin) Avoid if possible IV/IM

dosing.instructions: If aminoglycoside absolutely necessary, monitor peak/trough levels strictly; discontinue if vestibular symptoms develop
dosing.orderSentence: **Aminoglycosides** (gentamicin, tobramycin, streptomycin) Avoid if possible IV/IM

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.contraindications: Pre-existing vestibular dysfunction; concurrent ototoxic agents
Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Peak/trough levels; vestibular symptom assessment; audiometry if prolonged course

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Nystagmus is dose-dependent toxicity sign; gaze-evoked nystagmus appears before ataxia; monitor levels

dosing.instructions: Free phenytoin level; nystagmus = early toxicity warning; reduce dose immediately if nystagmus develops

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Free phenytoin level; nystagmus is early warning sign of toxicity

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Downbeat nystagmus and cerebellar toxicity; may be irreversible ("SILENT syndrome" — syndrome of irreversible lithium-effectuated neurotoxicity)

dosing.instructions: Lithium level STAT if nystagmus develops in lithium-treated patient; irreversible cerebellar damage possible

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Lithium level; nystagmus in lithium-treated patient — STAT level; monitor for SILENT syndrome

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.indication: Gaze-evoked nystagmus and ataxia at toxic levels; dose-dependent

dosing.instructions: Drug level; reduce dose; autoinduction may alter levels unpredictably

Medications to AVOID or Use with Caution.monitoring: Carbamazepine level; monitor for autoinduction; reduce dose if nystagmus develops

Referrals & Consults.item: Systematic nystagmus characterization: document direction, waveform (jerk vs. pendular), effect of gaze position, effect of fixation removal (Frenzel goggles), effect of convergence, effect of head position; this determines central vs. peripheral and guides workup

Frenzel goggles / fixation removal: **Critical for evaluation**; peripheral vestibular nystagmus INCREASES with fixation removal; central nystagmus is NOT suppressed by fixation; if no Frenzel goggles — have patient close eyes and observe for deviation, or use ophthalmoscope on one eye

Neurology consultation: all central nystagmus patterns; downbeat, upbeat, see-saw, convergence-retraction, direction-changing nystagmus; gaze-evoked nystagmus without drug cause; atypical positional nystagmus

Neuro-ophthalmology referral: persistent or unexplained nystagmus; oscillopsia affecting daily function; see-saw nystagmus; convergence-retraction nystagmus; complex oculomotor patterns; need for quantitative eye movement recording
Stroke consultation: if HINTS exam suggests central pattern in acute vestibular syndrome; any acute-onset central nystagmus pattern with vascular risk factors
ENT / Neurotology referral: peripheral vestibular nystagmus with hearing loss; recurrent BPPV; suspected Meniere's; intratympanic therapy evaluation
Vestibular rehabilitation referral: all patients with persistent oscillopsia or vestibular nystagmus; gaze stabilization exercises; balance training; habituation
Fall precautions: nystagmus with oscillopsia causes gait instability; assist with ambulation; home safety assessment; walker if needed
Ophthalmology referral: visual acuity assessment; retinal evaluation; optic disc examination; OCT if optic neuropathy suspected

Patient Instructions.item: Nystagmus explanation: your eyes are making involuntary movements that can cause blurred vision and a sensation that things are moving (oscillopsia); this is being evaluated to find and treat the cause

Medication adherence: take all prescribed medications exactly as directed; do NOT stop baclofen or clonazepam abruptly — this can cause seizures or dangerous withdrawal; report side effects before stopping

Oscillopsia coping strategies: use steady head positioning when reading; increase lighting and contrast; reduce screen time during acute symptoms; sit with back supported to reduce head movement; use large-print materials

Driving restrictions: do NOT drive if experiencing oscillopsia or visual instability; notify your neurologist before resuming driving; formal visual acuity testing may be required for driving clearance

Return to ED immediately if: sudden new weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking (stroke symptoms); sudden severe headache; sudden vision loss; worsening nystagmus with new neurologic symptoms; severe vomiting preventing medication intake; falls with head injury

Activity modification: avoid heights, ladders, and heavy machinery until nystagmus stabilized; use caution on stairs (use handrails); avoid rapid head movements that worsen symptoms; ask for assistance with ambulation if unsteady

Vestibular rehabilitation exercises: perform prescribed gaze stabilization exercises daily as instructed by physical therapy; exercises may initially worsen symptoms but improve compensation over time; report persistent worsening to provider
Alcohol avoidance: alcohol worsens nystagmus and impairs vestibular compensation; avoid alcohol completely during active treatment and evaluation

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Home safety assessment: remove trip hazards (loose rugs, cords); install grab bars in bathroom; ensure adequate lighting throughout home; non-slip mats in shower/bathtub

Visual environment optimization: use high-contrast materials for reading; avoid busy visual patterns (striped wallpaper, scrolling screens); use task lighting; matte finishes reduce glare-induced oscillopsia worsening

Medication review: review all current medications with provider for vestibulotoxic or nystagmus-causing agents; avoid over-the-counter sedating antihistamines; report any new medications to neurologist
Fall prevention program: balance exercises as prescribed by vestibular PT; wear supportive footwear; use assistive device (cane/walker) if recommended; avoid walking in dark or on uneven surfaces

Alcohol and substance avoidance: alcohol worsens nystagmus and impairs cerebellar function; avoid recreational substances that affect vestibular function; chronic alcohol use causes permanent cerebellar degeneration

Low vision support resources: contact local low vision rehabilitation services if oscillopsia affects reading, work, or daily activities; assistive technology (text-to-speech, magnification devices); occupational therapy referral

differential.tests: Defined by direction of fast phase; most common acquired type
No fast phase; often multidirectional or circular/elliptical

differential.features: Jerk in some positions, pendular in others

evidence.recommendation: Eye Movement Abnormalities in Clinical Diagnosis
evidence.evidenceLevel: Leigh & Zee, The Neurology of Eye Movements, 5th ed. (Oxford University Press)
3,4-Diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) reduced slow-phase velocity of downbeat nystagmus and improved visual acuity in placebo-controlled study
evidence.source: Established aminopyridine treatment for downbeat nystagmus; first randomized evidence

evidence.evidenceLevel: 4-AP 5 mg TID significantly reduced downbeat nystagmus intensity and oscillopsia vs. placebo in double-blind RCT
HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus pattern, Test of Skew) was 100% sensitive and 96% specific for stroke in acute vestibular syndrome
evidence.source: HINTS is standard for all acute vestibular syndrome; nystagmus pattern is key component

evidence.evidenceLevel: Baclofen abolished periodic alternating nystagmus in patients with craniocervical junction disease
evidence.source: Baclofen became standard treatment for PAN

evidence.evidenceLevel: 4-Aminopyridine restores vertical and horizontal neural integrator function in downbeat nystagmus
evidence.source: Demonstrated 4-AP mechanism of action in cerebellar oculomotor dysfunction

evidence.evidenceLevel: Meta-analysis: Individual HINTS components — normal head impulse test most predictive of central cause in acute vestibular syndrome
evidence.source: Direction-changing nystagmus and normal HIT = "dangerous" signs requiring stroke workup

evidence.evidenceLevel: 12-20% of posterior fossa strokes missed on early MRI (<48h) but detected on repeat imaging
evidence.source: If high clinical suspicion (central nystagmus pattern) and initial MRI negative, repeat MRI at 48-72h

evidence.evidenceLevel: Systematic review of aminopyridine treatment for cerebellar and oculomotor disorders; confirmed efficacy for downbeat nystagmus and episodic ataxia type 2
evidence.source: Supports aminopyridine use across cerebellar oculomotor disorders

evidence.evidenceLevel: Baclofen and cholinergic drugs effective for upbeat and downbeat nystagmus; demonstrated pharmacologic modulation of central vestibular nystagmus
evidence.source: GABAergic and cholinergic agents as treatment options for central nystagmus

evidence.evidenceLevel: Gabapentin and memantine both effective for acquired pendular nystagmus in MS patients
evidence.source: Established pharmacotherapy for acquired pendular nystagmus

monitoring.target: Complete classification; central vs. peripheral determination
monitoring.action: Central features — STAT MRI; neurology/stroke consultation

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (cranial nerves, cerebellar, motor, sensory)
monitoring.frequency: On presentation; q2h if central concern
monitoring.action: New deficits — stroke workup; expanding lesion
Hypertension — stroke concern; hypotension — volume depletion
Reduced VA with nystagmus — urgent neuro-ophthalmology

disposition.criteria: Posterior circulation stroke with acute nystagmus; basilar artery occlusion; cerebellar stroke with mass effect/hydrocephalus; altered consciousness with nystagmus

Acute central nystagmus requiring workup (MRI, vascular imaging); Wernicke encephalopathy requiring IV thiamine; intractable nausea/vomiting/oscillopsia; new neurologic deficits with nystagmus; medication toxicity requiring monitoring
Acute-onset nystagmus pending MRI; nystagmus with equivocal HINTS findings; serial neurologic exams needed
